Fun, but I'm left wondering what grants a three-star level. Using the least amount of items in my inventory to complete the level or hitting the goal closest to center? One level had ~6 items in the inventory. I reached the goal using only two items and received a single-star rating. What!? I used different items in the inventory and was eventually able to get a three-star rating. What!?  What!?  Yes, I'm the anal, over-achiever who wants three stars on every level, so it got old fast. I stopped playing because of the unpredictable ratings.

If you just to play through the levels and solve the puzzles without any concern for the ratings, this is a great puzzle game and utilizes controls and space well. 
*It has implemented blink/transport locomotion. 
*Controls are intuitive and work well with the environment.
*It would have been nice had they utilized true room-size room scale for this game. It would have made for a more enjoyable, more immersive experience.

31091999.review:
Bounce is a perfect example of how VR can be used to create new and entertaining experiences in three dimensions. The premise is simple, get a cute ball from one end of an obstacle course to the other using a limited set of pieces and a limited number of attempts at trial and error along the way.

What sets Bounce apart from a lot of tepid VR puzzlers is that it takes full advantage of all three dimensions. The ball usually starts in the ceiling, and you have a limited amount of momentum to get it quite some distance to a target that could also be up in the ceiling, or behind numerous baffles, or only after finding a way to get through several hoops between start and finish.

Bounce earns distinction not only for the puzzles, but its soundtrack as well. The audio is enjoyable (except for the sad, sad sound of D1G-B hitting a bulkhead - and even that's amusing). The graphics are up to snuff and the game looks polished and professional.

If I have a disappointment with the game, it's that it doesn't tell you what "par" is for each course. Figuring out that style doesn't matter (in the first go-round) only the number of times you test your pathway for D1G-B was both mildly frustrating and a minor let down.

All in all, if you enjoy puzzle games, Bounce is a great one to buy.

For puzzle lovers with a VR device capable of roomscale and handtracking, this is a must.
